metadata.description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.

content:
Drug: Amphetamine | cid: 3007
Source: erowid | Source description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.
Erowid name: amphetamines
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Chemistry

                    Text: 
                    ("Share Your Story" link. Needs quick login creation but no verification of contact info)

NAME : Amphetamine CHEMICAL NAME : (±)-alpha-Methylbenzeneethanamine ALTERNATE CHEMICAL NAMES : dl-alpha-methylphenethylamine, 1-phenyl-2-aminopropane, beta-aminopropylbenzene ALTERNATE CHEMICAL NAMES : racemic desoxy-nor-ephedrine, Actedron, Allodene, Adipan, Sympatedrine ALTERNATE CHEMICAL NAMES : Psychedrine, Isomyn, Isoamyne, Mecodrin, Norephedrane, Novydrine, Elastonon ALTERNATE CHEMICAL NAMES : Ortedrine, Phenedrine, Profamina, Propisamine, Sympamine, Simpatedrin CHEMICAL FORMULA C 9 H 13 N MOLECULAR WEIGHT 135.21 From the Merck Index 12th Edition


                    Context: 
                    This chunk appears at the beginning of Erowid's detailed chemical profile for amphetamine, listing its official name, primary chemical name, multiple alternate chemical names, chemical formula, and molecular weight as referenced in the Merck Index. It serves as an identification summary before more in-depth information on properties, synthesis, and research citations.

metadata.title: Erowid Amphetamines Vault : Chemistry
metadata.description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.

content:
Drug: Amphetamine | cid: 3007
Source: erowid | Source description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.
Erowid name: amphetamines
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Chemistry

                    Text: 
                    623. Amphetamine. (±)-alpha-Methylbenzenethanamine; dl-alpha-methylphenethylamine; 1-phenyl-2-aminopropane; (phenylisopropyl)amine; ß-aminopropylbenzene; racemic desoxy-nor-ephedrine; Acetedron; Allodene; Adipan; Sympatedrine; Psychedrine; Isomyn; Isoamyne; Mecodrin; Norephadrane; Novydrine; Elastonon; Ortedrine; Phenedrine; Profamina; Propisamine; Sympamine; Simpatedrin. CHN; mol wt 135.21. C 79.95%, H 9.69%, N 10.36%, Prepn: U.S. pats. 1,879,003 (1932); 1,921,424 (1933); 2,015,408 (1935); Hartung, Munch, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 53, 1875 (1931). Demonstration of sterospecific binding sites for (+)-³H-amphetamine in hypothalamic membranes and correlations with anorexic potency of phenylethylamines: S. M. Paul et al., Science 218, 487 (1982). Toxicity data: M.R. Warren, H.W. Werner, J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 85, 119 (1945); W.A. Behrendt, R. Deininger, Arzneimittel-Forsch. 13, 711 (1963). Series of articles on the biochemical and behavioral effects of amphetamines in man and animals: Handb.


                    Context: 
                    This chunk provides detailed chemical, physical, and bibliographic data on amphetamine, including its synonyms, molecular composition, preparation patents, toxicity references, and pharmacological studies. It appears within Erowid’s comprehensive chemical index, specifically under the amphetamines section, offering in-depth scientific and historical context for the substance.

metadata.title: Erowid Amphetamines Vault : Chemistry
metadata.description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.

content:
Drug: Amphetamine | cid: 3007
Source: erowid | Source description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.
Erowid name: amphetamines
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Chemistry

                    Text: 
                    Exp. Ther. 85, 119 (1945); W.A. Behrendt, R. Deininger, Arzneimittel-Forsch. 13, 711 (1963). Series of articles on the biochemical and behavioral effects of amphetamines in man and animals: Handb. Exp. Pharmakol. 45, 3-304 (1977); Handb. Psycho pharmacol. 11, 1-98 (1978). Review of use and abuse: J. P. Morgan, Substance Abuse: Clinical Problems and Perspectives, J. H. Lowinson, P. Ruiz, Eds. (Williams C Wilkins, Baltimore, 1981) pp 167-184. Books: C. D. Leake, The Amphetamines: Their Actions and Uses (Thomas, Spring field, 1958) 167 pp; O. J. Kalant, The Amphetamines: Toxicity and Addiction (Thomas, Springfield, 1966) 151 pp. Mobile liquid. Amine odor. Acrid, burning taste. Vola tilizes slowly at room temp, d 0.913. bp, 200-203°; bp 82-85°. Slightly soluble in water; sol in alc, ether; readily sol in acids. Aq solns are alkaline to litmus. LD in rats (mg/kg): 180 s.c. (Warren, Werner). Sulfate, (CHN).HSO, Alentol, Benzedrine, Psychoton, Simpamina. Crystals. Slightly bitter taste


                    Context: 
                    This chunk appears in the detailed chemical profile for amphetamine on Erowid, following references to scientific studies and reviews on its effects, toxicity, and abuse. It transitions from scholarly citations and book references about amphetamines to a description of the compound's physical properties (appearance, odor, taste, solubility), pharmacological effects, and toxicological data.

metadata.title: Erowid Amphetamines Vault : Chemistry
metadata.description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.

content:
Drug: Amphetamine | cid: 3007
Source: erowid | Source description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.
Erowid name: amphetamines
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Chemistry

                    Text: 
                    readily sol in acids. Aq solns are alkaline to litmus. LD in rats (mg/kg): 180 s.c. (Warren, Werner). Sulfate, (CHN).HSO, Alentol, Benzedrine, Psychoton, Simpamina. Crystals. Slightly bitter taste followed by sensation of numbness. mp above 300° (dec). One part dissolves in 8.8 parts water, 515 parts 95% ale. A soln of 1 g/10 ml water has a pH 5-6. LD in mice, rats (mg/kg): 24.2, 55 orally (Behrendt, Deininger). Phosphate, CHN.HPO, Actemin, Aktedron, Monophos, Profetamine Phosphate, Racephen, Raphatamine Phosphate. Prepn: Goggin, U.S. pat. 2,507,468 (1950 to Clark & Clark). Crystals, bitter taste. Sinters at about 150°. Dec around 300°. More sol in water than amphetamine sulfate. Slightly sol in alcohol. Practically insol in benzene, chloroform, ether. The pH of a 10% soln is about 4.6. d-Form tannate, tanphetamin, Synatan. Prepn: Cavallito, U.S. pat. 2,950,309 (1960 to Irwin, Neisler and Co.). d-Form sulfate, see Dextroamphetamine Sulfate. l-Form, levamphetamine, levamfetamine.


                    Context: 
                    This chunk provides detailed physicochemical properties, solubility, melting points, tastes, and toxicity (LD) data for various amphetamine salts and forms (sulfate, phosphate, tannate), situating it within the document’s broader chemical reference entry for amphetamine, including synonyms, chemistry, synthesis, and toxicology.

metadata.title: Erowid Amphetamines Vault : Chemistry
metadata.description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.

content:
Drug: Amphetamine | cid: 3007
Source: erowid | Source description: Information and images about the chemistry of amphetamines.
Erowid name: amphetamines
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Chemistry

                    Text: 
                    d-Form tannate, tanphetamin, Synatan. Prepn: Cavallito, U.S. pat. 2,950,309 (1960 to Irwin, Neisler and Co.). d-Form sulfate, see Dextroamphetamine Sulfate. l-Form, levamphetamine, levamfetamine. l-Form succinate, Cydril. Note: This is a controlled substance (stimulant) listed in the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations, Title 21 Part 1308.12 (1995). THERAP CAT: CNS stimulant; anorexic. THERAP CAT (VET): CNS stimulant, in narcotic poisoning anesthetic collapse, in depression from encephalitis.


                    Context: 
                    This chunk details specific chemical forms and derivatives of amphetamine, including d-Form tannate, d-Form sulfate, l-Form, and l-Form succinate, their trade names, and associated patents. It also notes amphetamine's status as a controlled stimulant under U.S. law and summarizes its therapeutic uses for the central nervous system in both humans and veterinary medicine. This information appears in the comprehensive chemical profile for amphetamine, which includes nomenclature, synthesis, toxicity, and pharmacological data.
